wxVtkTest2.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 import vtk
00002 from vtk.wx.wxVTKRenderWindow import *
00003 import wx
00004 from pylab import *
00005 
00006 def Intensity(x=[],y=[],z=[],Ex = []):
00007 
00008     #here i input the points in x,y,z form an Ex is the intensity of each point
00009     # every wx app needs an app
00010     app = wxPySimpleApp()
00011 
00012     # create the widget
00013     frame = wxFrame(None, -1, "First plot ", size=wxSize(400,400))
00014     widget = wxVTKRenderWindow(frame, -1)
00015 
00016     ren = vtk.vtkRenderer()
00017     widget.GetRenderWindow().AddRenderer(ren)
00018     numberOfOutputPoints = len(x)
00019     # Create a float array which represents the points.
00020     pcoords = vtk.vtkFloatArray()
00021     # Note that by default, an array has 1 component.
00022     # We have to change it to 3 for points
00023     pcoords.SetNumberOfComponents(3)
00024     # We ask pcoords to allocate room for at least 4 tuples
00025     # and set the number of tuples to 4. now 6
00026     pcoords.SetNumberOfTuples(numberOfOutputPoints)
00027     # Assign each tuple. There are 5 specialized versions of SetTuple:
00028     # SetTuple1 SetTuple2 SetTuple3 SetTuple4 SetTuple9
00029     # These take 1, 2, 3, 4 and 9 components respectively.
00030     x1 =0
00031     y1 =0
00032     z1 =0
00033     for i in range(0,numberOfOutputPoints):
00034         x1= x[i]; y1 = y[i]; z1 = z[i]
00035         pcoords.SetTuple3(i, x1, y1, z1)
00036         #print i,x1,y1,z1
00037 
00038     # Create vtkPoints and assign pcoords as the internal data array.
00039     points = vtk.vtkPoints()
00040     points.SetData(pcoords)
00041     #points.SetRadius(0.5)
00042 
00043     # Create the cells. In this case, a triangle strip with 2 triangles
00044     # (which can be represented by 4 points)
00045 
00046     strips = vtk.vtkCellArray()
00047     strips.InsertNextCell(numberOfOutputPoints)
00048     for i in range(0, numberOfOutputPoints):
00049         strips.InsertCellPoint(i)
00050 
00051     # Create an integer array with 4 tuples. Note that when using
00052     # InsertNextValue (or InsertNextTuple1 which is equivalent in
00053     # this situation), the array will expand automatically
00054      
00055     temperature = vtk.vtkDoubleArray()
00056     temperature.SetName("Temperature")
00057     #temp = arange(1,60,10)
00058     temp =Ex
00059     for i in temp :
00060         temperature.InsertNextValue(i)
00061 
00062     # Create the dataset. In this case, we create a vtkPolyData
00063     polydata = vtk.vtkPolyData()
00064     # Assign points and cells
00065     polydata.SetPoints(points)
00066     polydata.SetStrips(strips)
00067     # Assign scalars
00068 
00069     polydata.GetPointData().SetScalars(temperature)
00070 
00071     # Create the mapper and set the appropriate scalar range
00072     # (default is (0,1)
00073     mapper = vtk.vtkPolyDataMapper()
00074     mapper.SetInput(polydata)
00075     mapper.SetScalarRange(0, max(temp))
00076 
00077     actor = vtk.vtkActor()
00078     actor.SetMapper(mapper)
00079 
00080     #########################################################
00081 
00082     #########################################################
00083 
00084     ren.AddActor(actor)
00085     ren.SetBackground( 1.0, 1.0, 1.0 )
00086 
00087     frame.Show(1)
00088 
00089     app.MainLoop()
00090     
00091 if __name__=='__main__':
00092     x=[1,2]
00093     y=[1,2]
00094     z=[1,2]
00095     ex=[1,2]
00096     Intensity(x,y,z,ex)
